column4: I have created a directory called, "/vmfiles/vm" However, if I go into the vmfiles directory and run "ls" it does not display the vm directory. But I can still navigate to /vmfiles/vm. Any ideas why vm does not show up in ls?
So no one has any idea why the "ls" command fails to execute properly? It works fine in all directories except the one I created.
no read permission on the dir ?
it doesn't say anything. I execute the command and it returns me to the prompt. No output
root____, I thought if I created the directory using sudo, that I automatically had read permissions. how would I check the permissions?

Here's the details: I have created a directory called, "/vmfiles/vm" However, if I go into the vmfiles directory and run "ls" it does not display the vm directory. But I can still navigate to /vmfiles/vm. Any ideas why vm does not show up in ls?
why did you use sudo ?    is the dir not in your home ?
root_________ correct, it is a directory sitting on the root of the filesystem.
ok ls -l /   to see the ownership and permissions of the dir in question
root___, this is the readout: http://pastebin.ubuntu-uk.org/46402
wait! Holdup. Something goofy is going on.
oh, I ran that command. At the very top of the pastebin is the relevent directory from that command
but! I fixed the issue. Turns out to be a linux hiccup
I restarted my machine and saw (bizzarrly) that my subdirectory moved itself to the root directory.
Thanks for helping me out guys.
ah yes line one,,  1. drwxr-xr-x  2 root root  4096 2009-01-21 17:08 vmfiles    sorry.  anyway you have read access.   if you want write access you'll have to chmod it
